subsections.title: Gerund
structure: verb + ing → functions as a noun
examples: eating, playing, driving
subsections.explanation: A gerund looks like a verb but acts like a noun.

subsections.title: Infinitive
examples: to eat, to play, to go
subsections.explanation: Used for purpose, goals, and after specific verbs.

subsections.title: GERUND as subject
examples: Cleaning is hard work.
Walking to work every day has helped my back.
Driving without a seat belt is dangerous.
Smoking has many negative effects.
subsections.explanation: If you want a verb as the subject, use a gerund.

subsections.title: INFINITIVE as subject
examples: To love is to admire with the heart.
To be or not to be.
To study so long and quit seems like a waste.
To become a doctor was her dream.
To pass this class is my only goal.
subsections.explanation: Infinitive subjects sound formal, abstract, or related to goals.

subsections.title: INFINITIVE = purpose
examples: I wear glasses to see.
You need to be 18 to vote.
The company installed cameras to make employees feel safer.
To listen to the message again, press one.
subsections.explanation: Use to + verb when explaining why.

subsections.title: LIST 1: Verbs ALWAYS followed by a gerund
examples: I avoid sitting in the sun.
Learning a language involves studying daily.
subsections.explanation: These verbs MUST be followed by -ing.

subsections.title: LIST 2: Verbs ALWAYS followed by the infinitive
examples: I finally managed to find a babysitter.
My son refuses to eat vegetables.
subsections.explanation: These verbs MUST be followed by to + verb.

subsections.title: LIST 3: Verb + object + infinitive
examples: I asked to see the menu. / I asked my friend to help me.
Please remind me to call mom.
subsections.explanation: When someone else does the action → object + to + verb.

subsections.title: LIST 4: Either gerund OR infinitive (no change in meaning)
examples: I can't stand seeing you sad. / I can't stand to see you sad.
They started shouting. / They started to shout.
subsections.explanation: Both forms are correct with the same meaning.

subsections.title: LIST 5: Verbs that CHANGE meaning (very important)
examples: Remember: Gerund = memory, Infinitive = obligation
Forget: Gerund = forget memory, Infinitive = forget to do
Try: Gerund = experiment, Infinitive = attempt
Stop: Gerund = quit activity, Infinitive = stop to do another
Regret: Gerund = feel guilty, Infinitive = announce bad news
subsections.explanation: These verbs change meaning depending on gerund or infinitive.

subsections.title: 1. Remember
examples: I remember learning to swim. (memory)
I remember seeing a man with a suitcase. (memory)
Remember to cancel your appointment. (obligation)
He remembered to turn off the stove. (obligation)

subsections.title: 2. Forget
examples: I'll never forget playing with my childhood friend. (memory)
I forgot to take out the trash. (obligation)
He forgot to get gas. (obligation)

subsections.title: 3. Try
examples: Have you tried meditating? (experiment)
Have you tried drinking herbal tea? (experiment)
I'll try to do that pose. (attempt)
I tried to get tickets, but they were sold out. (attempt)

subsections.title: 4. Stop
structure: Infinitive = stop one action to do another
examples: Please stop chewing your gum. (quit activity)
I stopped going to French class. (quit activity)
I stopped to take pictures. (stop to do another)
The car stopped to let the ambulance pass. (stop to do another)

subsections.title: 5. Regret
structure: Gerund = feel guilty about a past action
examples: I regret not spending more time with my grandma. (feel guilty)
I regret eating all those donuts. (feel guilty)
We regret to inform you that your application was rejected. (announce)
I regret to announce she is leaving. (announce)
